title-group.article-title: "Group Drinkards Maaks Grope Thinkards": Narrative in the "Norwegian Captain" Episode of "Finnegans Wake"

ref.mixed-citation: Ole Vinding, "James Joyce in Copenhagen" in Portraits of the Artist in Exile: Recollections of James Joyce by Europeans, ed. Willard Potts (Seattle- Univ. of Washington Press, 1979), p. 149.
Gadamer, "Hermeneutics as a The- oretical and Practical Task" and "Hermeneutics as Practical Philosophy" in Reason in the Age of Science (Cambridge: MIT Press, 1983)
Paul Ricoeur, "On Interpretation" in Philosophy in France Today, ed. Alan Montefiore (Cambridge: Cambridge Univ. Press, 1983).
Jurgen Habermas, The Philosophical Discourse of Modernity (Cambridge: MIT Press, 1990), pp. 12-15
John Bishop, Joyce's Book of the Dark: "Finnegans Wake" (Madison: Univ. of Wisconsin Press, 1986). Subsequent references to Bishop's book will be cited parenthetically in the text as B.
Bernard Benstock's recent anti-narrative reading of the Wake, which centers on its representational discontinuities, can be found in James Joyce (New York: Frederick Ungar, 1985)
"The Anti-Schematics of Finnegans Wake," Joyce Studies Annual 1990, pp.96-116.

David Hayman's compelling "nodal" theory, with its narrative model of interflecting textual clusters, has been developed in Re-forming the Narrative: Toward a Mechanics of Modernism (Ithaca: Cornell Univ. Press, 1987)
The "Wake" in Transit (Ithaca: Cornell Univ, Press, 1990).
John Gordon, "Finnegans Wake": A Plot Summary (Dublin: Gill and Macmillan, 1986)
Michael Begnal, Dreamscheme (Syracuse: Syracuse Univ. Press, 1988).
Begnal, who believes that "there still remains a novelistic form and structure behind or below the complications of the novel's primary linguistic level" (p. 51)
Eugene Jolas, "My Friend James Joyce" in James Joyce: Two Decades of Criticism, ed. Seon Givens (New York: Vanguard Press, 1948), pp. 11-12.
Laurence Sterne, The Life and Opinions of Tristram Shandy, Gentleman (New York: The New English Library 1962), pp. 384-86.
Begnal has some nice observations on the relationship between Tristram Shandy and the Wake in Dreamscheme, pp. 30, 66-68.
Roland McHugh, The Sigla of "Finnegans Wake" (Austin: Univ. of Texas Press, 1976), p. 75.
Ilya Prigogine, From Being to Becoming: Time and Complexity in the Physical Sciences (San Francisco: H. Freeman, 1980)
Bergson's devolu- tion creatrice (Paris: E Alcan, 1914)
Joseph Solomon's guidebook Bergson (London: Constable, 1912)
John Paul Ri- quelme, Teller and Tale in Joyce's Fiction: Oscillating Perspectives (Baltimore: Johns Hopkins Univ. Press, 1983), pp. 11-12,
Sigmund Freud, in The Interpretation of Dreams, ed. James Strachey (New York: Basic Books, 1972), pp.138-51.
Roy Schafer, "Narration in the Psychoanalytic Dialogue/' in On Narrative (Chicago: Univ. of Chicago Press, 1981)
William York Tindall's A Reader's Guide to "Finnegans Wake" (New York: Farrar, Straus and Giroux, 1969).
Tindall refers to Freud's "dreamwork" as a way of accounting for the Wake's general processes (pp. 18-19)
Roland McHugh in The Sigla of "Finnegans Wake" (pp, 77-81)
Cheryl Herr, Joyce's Anatomy of Culture (Urbana and Chi- cago: Univ. of Illinois Press, 1986), pp. 96435,
The Interpretation of Dreams, pp. 531-33
Roland McHugh, Annotations to 'Finnegans Wake" (Baltimore: Johns Hopkins Univ. Press, 1980), pp. 28, 327.
Bishop's suggestion that HCE "harbors a great deal of bottled-up animosity" toward his "uniform" (p. 129)
his speculations on how "the whole matter of 'telling'.. .is necessarily 'retailored' and formally altered in Fin- negans Wake" (p. 130)
my reading of the Wake and also inspired me to challenge many of his statements on narrative in general, and on the "Norwegian Captain" episode (pp. 279-80)
Lacan's early general essay on this subject, "The Mirror Stage," in Ecrits (New York: Norton, 1977)
Kimberly Devlin's "Self and Other in Finnegans Wake: A Framework for Analyzing Versions of Shem and Shaun/' JJQ, 21 (Fall 1983), 31-50
her "'See Ourselves as Others See Us7: Joyce's Look at the Eye of the Other," PMLA, 104 (October 1989), 882-93.
A. Ansted's A Dictionary of Sea Terms (Glasgow: James Brown and Son, 1919)
The Lore of Sail (New York: Facts on File^ 1983).
McHugh, Annotations, p. 312.
Bishop's explication of HCE's radio in terms of human ear structure (pp. 276-77)
his related essay on the sleeper's anxiety and bewilder- ment consequent to the inexorable reception of sound (pp. 284-85).
